text: when it comes to what things look like
the Western world is obsessed by
Perfection by Symmetry and ideal
proportion this is a taste for beauty
shaped by a reverence for universal laws
mathematics and an appetite for the
perfect and the Eternal Japanese
Aesthetics are however very different
indeed and the core of the difference is
captured in a term term for which
Western languages have no direct
equivalent a term known as wabby saabi
wabby saabi refers to the beauty of the
impermanent the imperfect The Rustic and
The Melancholy it derives not from a
love of invincibility Youth and
flawlessness but from a respect for what
is passing fragile slightly broken and
modest wabby saabi believes that things
are always more beautiful for bearing
the marks of age and individuality a
trickle of Glade or a beautifully
repaired crack on a piece of pottery are
to be appreciated rather than made
invisible Webby saab's history is
intimately linked with Buddhism and its
suggestion that wisdom comes from making
peace with our transitory imperfect and
unheroic
Natures kushu Japan
1191 a monk known as aay returns to
Japan from China with plans to create
Japan's first Zen Buddhist temple Zen
presents a challenge to Japan's
indigenous religions Shinto Zen offers a
complex philosophical system which
presents nature with its constant cycles
of life and imperfect patterns as a
focus of meditation and a lens through
which to understand our own transience
and emptiness Zen will go on to be the
philosophical Bedrock of wabby
sabii 14th century Japan the meaning of
two words wabby and sabii begin to
evolve and become more positive than
they had been wabby had originally meant
the misery and L L less of living in
nature away from Human consolation but
its meaning now shifts to refer to an
almost Exquisite Bittersweet Melancholy
at being on one's own sabii meanwhile
which had originally meant chill lean or
withered starts to denote the marks of
aging and wear which can enhance an
object it refers to a positive
impermanence and the welcome and Noble
signs of time the ancient patterner of a
pot or a crack beautifully mended are
now called
sabii Kyoto 1488 Morata shuko sits down
to write a letter to his student fui
choin this document will come to be
known as the letter of the heart and
will Define the ideal way that one
should drink tea the tea ceremony and
lays out the aesthetic of wabby sabii
the Tea Ceremony had originated as a way
for monks to stay awake in order to
practice long periods of Zen meditation
but recently it's been overtaken by the
ruling class of Warlords or Shoguns they
use it as a way of showing off expensive
vessels and utensils imported from China
the Tea Ceremony has become flashy often
in elaborate and gudy surroundings and
has slipped a long way from its
spiritual Roots now shuko redesigns the
Tea Ceremony with the ideals of wabby
saabi in mind the fashion at the time is
to enjoy tea on a balcony while looking
at the full moon but Shuka claims that
he has no taste for the full moon in
instead he urges his student to
appreciate the more subtle interplay of
Shadows on the half of the moon or the
partially clouded Moon he also stresses
that one should abandon the perfect and
lustrous tea drinking cups of the
Chinese which seem to evoke the
flawlessness of the full moon and
instead to commission more rustic wear
from Japanese Artisans who will make
little errors in the glaze and let these
be a deliberate part of their work Kyoto
1582 Senor Riku is summoned to the
service of toyotomi hidoshi a powerful
warlord who unites the Waring factions
of feudal Japan he commissions Ru to
create a tea ceremony that can help to
Foster peace along with shuko Seno Rio
is revered in Japan as the father of the
modern tea ceremony and the most perfect
practitioner of wabby saabi a story that
is most often used to illustrate the
spirit of wabby saabi is taken from his
life one day Ru asked a disciple to
clean his tea house and the young boy
worked all day to scrub and and sweep
every inch of the House and Garden when
rku came to inspect it he reached up and
shook a maple tree overhanging the path
the sprinkling of leaves that fell
brought wabby saabi to the scene thus
the man-made and the natural artifice
and random chants were United in a
perfect expression of beauty and wisdom
Riku goes further than shuko in
undermining the high tastes of the
Shoguns and strips everything
non-essential from his tea ceremony the
pots he uses are often directly taken
from peasant environments or are modeled
after a particularly rustic roof tile
that he spots while walking through a
local Village Ru also codifies the
movements of the Tea Ceremony creating
the perfectly economical and graceful
motions for preparing tea with a minimum
of fuss thereby adding wabby saabi to
the very core of the ritual
unfortunately for rku his boss the
warlord hioshi comes from a peasant
background and begins to fear that the
whole process is maybe an elaborate joke
at his expense
this causes him to order rku to commit
harakiri in an eerie parallel to
socrates's demise rku holds a final te
ceremony among his closest friends
before obediently stabbing himself
through the stomach today all the great
schools of te Trace their lineage back
to rku and all follow the motions and
traditions that he set out the maker of
the humble tile that he so admired was
known as Raku and Raku pots are still
made today and appreciated as the
greatest embodiment of Webby saabi if
you take tea in the the silver Pavilion
in Kyoto the birthplace of the formal
tea ceremony in Japan you can drink from
the same cup as the Troublesome hit
Yoshi once sipped
from Ido 1684 matsuo baso the father of
the Haiku and Japan's most revered poet
sets off on the first of his great
pilgrimages these aimless wanderings
will take him to the heart of solitude
and nature and help him to capture the
spirit of wabby saabi in words a
depressive with a great talent baso
takes joy in wandering the dangerous
roads around Ido disguised as a beggar
here he distills The Fragile beauty of
the sights around him into poetry that
tries to spot the Eternal through the
fleeting moment we can hear the
beautiful desolation in one of his most
famous haikus solitary now standing
amidst the blossoms is a cypress
tree ginsa District Tokyo 2013 an
enormous new outlet of Louis Von opens
built by the Japanese architect Yun Aoki
45% of all Japanese women are now
estimated to own a bag by the French
luxury goods firm featuring Western
ideals of shininess Perfection and
symmetry wabisabi is like many
traditional Japanese ideas under
enormous threat from the consumerist
values of the West webis saabi is at one
level an idea that relates to Pottery
drinking tea in the history of Japan but
at another it's a lesson for all of us
for all times because the place we
really have to come to terms with
imperfection Melancholy and age is in
ourselves eles wabby saabi is a giant
marketing effort which urges us to take
a second look at what we might otherwise
dismiss or treat with disdain it
recognizes that our tastes are not fixed
and that if someone with talent and
artistic Grace urges us to look more
sympathetically at some Moss a slightly
wonky teacup or indeed the wise wrinkled
face of a friend or relative we will be
able to find charm and Beauty here too
our Notions of beauty and interest are
relative and open to change and
Improvement with the ideals of Webby
saabi in mind we may learn to find
greater satisfaction in the humbler
moments in a walk down a slightly
crooked path on an overcast autumn day
or in a less than blemish free house
face or
Soul if you like our films take a look
at our shop the schoolof
life.com shop you'll find lots of
thoughtful books games stationer and
more let's say you just had a big r with
someone close to you they behaved
terribly maybe broke something and said
something hideous to you it's so
tempting to give up on them and just
hate them but there's another
